results.title: The Battle of Britain
results.creator_credit: Anthony Veiller, Frank Capra and United States. Office of War Information. Overseas Operations Branch
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Why we fight”.
Illustrates the German air attack on Britain, particularly London, by the use of film shot during World War II. The role of civilians in the Battle of Britain is highlighted. Concentrates on the Blitz in London and Coventry after Dunkirk, combining actuality footage with many extracts from fiction films. This film is credited with reducing anti-British sentiment among American forces.

results.title: Battle for the Bulge
results.brief_description: Uses location filming and historical footage to document the ‘Battle for the Bulge’, the last big German offensive in World War II. Portrays the heroism, as well as the confusion and humiliation, that characterised both the Allied and German troops.

results.title: Battle for bread
results.creator_credit: Richard De Rochemont, March of Time, Inc. and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description: The film stresses the importance of food in a world that has never produced enough for everyone, and describes the efforts of FAO to stimulate food production in many countries. After a preliminary survey of the food problem in war-torn countries, the film describes the working of the FAO program; agricultural machinery to China, international conferences on poison sprays for insects, the fight against animal diseases, encouragement to farmers to grow new kinds of crops.

results.title: Bats, birds and bionics
results.creator_credit: John MacDonald, Isaac Kleinerman and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Demonstrates the application of the principles of natural systems in living animals such as bats, rattlesnakes, frogs and rats, to engineering devices to guide blind persons, self guiding missiles, photoelectric scanners capable of distinguishing shapes and bionic computers designed to learn and to control man-like robots. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Batman's village
results.creator_credit: Ivor P. Kershaw and Factual Films of Australia
results.brief_description: A picturesque view of Melbourne city interspersed with factual information on its history and the key figures involved in its establishment. Inner city streets, buildings and botanical gardens are shown.

results.title: Bathing the bed patient
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Care of the sick and injured”.
Procedure for making a bed with a minimum of disturbance to the patient. Also demonstrates the proper method of washing the patient with as much comfort as posible.

results.title: Bate's car: sweet as a nut
results.creator_credit: Tony Ianzelo, Colin Low, Michael Rubbo and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A delightful film encounter with a man who found his own substitute for gasoline in barnyard manure. Mr. Bate is an inventor, a classic combination of single-minded knowhow and practical dreamer. But his discovery is real enough. The film shows how his homemade digester does turn manure into potent methane gas to power his auto. And for good measure he demonstrates his latest energy machine - a bicycle powered by the bumps on the road. Award: Yugoslavia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Ianzelo, Colin Low, Michael Rubbo and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Bat, a ball and a boy
results.brief_description: Famous Australian cricketers, including Sir Donald Bradman, Richie Benaud, Ray Lindwall, Len Hutton and Neil Harvey illustrate how to improve a boy’s game from batting to bowling to fielding. Includes archival footage of some of Australia’s greatest players.

results.title: Bassoon and contrabassoon
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Music Techniques”.
One of a series of films designed to assist the musician and the music lover. In this film professional musicians show how the bassoon and contrabassoon are made, and played, demonstrate their range and tone, and show how to care for them.
